description.narrative:
Ett konsortium av partners bestående av Trossamfundet Svenska Kyrkan, SvK (Church of Sweden – CoS), Action Against Hunger (ACF), Norska Flyktingrådet (NRC) och Lutherska Världsförbundet (LWF) har föreslagit ett program: ''Mutual and inter-related resilience Programme – MIRP” under 2019-2023 som syftar till att skapa varaktiga lösningar för flyktingar och värdsamhällen i västra Uganda kring Kyangwali flyktingbosättning och kringliggande områden, med fokus på nexus mellan humanitärt stöd och utvecklingssamarbete.
Ugandas progressiva flyktingpolitik främjar initiativ som driver flyktingagendan utöver humanitär hjälp med fokus på långsiktig utveckling och hållbara lösningar för flyktingar och värdsamhällen. De utdragna kriserna i flyktingarnas hemländer, exempelvis Sydsudan och DR Kongo, gör att flyktingarna i Uganda sannolikt åtminstone på kort sikt inte kommer att återvända till sina hemländer, vilket kräver att man fokuserar på åtgärder som syftar till integration av flyktingar i Uganda.
Ett antal integrationsåtgärder har genomförts i Uganda, såsom ”Self-reliance strategy” från1998, Development Assistance to Refugee-Hosting Areas programme (2004) och den nuvarande Settlement Transformative Agenda (STA), som syftar till att hjälpa flyktingar och värdsamhällen genom att främja självförsörjande, investeringar och social ekonomisk utveckling i flyktingbosättningar. Baserat på dessa tidigare insatser kommer MIRP att fokusera på kvarstående utmaningar som måste lösas för att uppnå självförsörjande, motståndskraft och utveckling i Kyangwali och kringliggande områden.
Det övergripande målet med MIRP är att rättighetsbärare (målgrupper, inklusive flyktingar och värdsamhällen) har uppnått resilienta samhällen, samt ökat ekonomiskt självförsörjande och psykosocialt välbefinnande vid slutet av insatsen. Programmet syftar till att uppnå detta mål genom lösningsorienterade åtgärder som både möter akuta behov och samtidigt stärker lokal kapacitet, samt utveckling av långsiktiga, hållbara lösningar kopplat till den långvariga flyktingkrisen i Kyangwali och omgivande områden.
De förväntade resultaten av insatsen är:
1. Förbättrad kvalitet kopplat till läskunnighet, räkning och kompetensutveckling i Kyangwali bosättning och kringliggande distrikt 2. Förbättrad självförsörjande och livsmedelssäkerhet för både värdbefolkning och flyktingar 3. Miljöskydd och hållbar energi för både värdbefolkning och flyktingar samt 4. Ökad tillgång till vatten, sanitet och skydd (inklusive förebyggande av könsbaserat våld, samt främjande av jämställdhet) och SRHR-tjänster
MIRP-programmet definierar ett "resilient samhälle" som "ett samhälle där medlemmarna är aktivt engagerade i socioekonomisk utveckling och de grundläggande behoven hos utsatta människor möts". Programmet syftar till att öka kapaciteten hos kommunerna i Hoima och Kikuube-distriktet för att planera och integrera flyktingfrågor genom stöd till infrastruktur och tjänster inom nyckelområden som utbildning, hälsa, vatten, jordbruk, försörjning och kompetensutveckling.
Inom utbildning, läskunnighet, räkning och kompetensutveckling syftar programmet till ökade anställningsmöjligheter, möjligheter till inkomstgenerering bland ungdomar genom kompetensutbildning, ökad kunskap och färdigheter (marknadsorienterade yrken, självförsörjande, entreprenörskap, språk, läskunnighet och räkning). Programmet kommer att stödja upprättande av infrastruktur som klassrum och latriner samt erhålla vatten och sanitet i skolor, viktiga faktorer till att studenter hoppar av utbildningen.
Programmet kommer att stödja insatser med fokus på försörjning och livsmedelssäkerhet för både flykting- och värdsamhällen genom att maximera användningen av markområden som är tilldelade flyktingar genom klimatsmarta åtgärder, användning av förbättrade grödor, jordbruksförbättring, kommersiellt jordbruk i värdsamhällen och mikrobevattning.
Programmet förväntas vidare hantera miljöförstöring kopplat till det stora antalet flyktingar och beroendet av ved för energi. För att undvika negativ inverkan på miljö och klimat kommer en miljökonsekvensbedömning och plan att genomföras för Kyangwali och dess omgivning för att hantera frågor som rör nedbrytning av naturresurser och miljö. Andra åtgärder avser hållbara lösningar för förnybar energi, korrekt avfallshantering och ökad miljömedvetenhet.
Programmet kommer att stödja vatten och sanitet, sexuell reproduktiv hälsa och skyddsinsatser (inklusive förebyggande av könsbaserat våld och jämställdhet). Dessa aktiviteter anses vara kritiska för att adressera SGBV och utmaningar som begränsade möjligheter för kvinnliga flyktingar, sårbarhet mot sexuellt våld och utnyttjande, långa avstånd för att hämta vatten och andra resurser. Det kommer även att adressera behov vad gäller tjänster kopplat till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR).
Insatsens totala budget är 159 720 000 kronor och aktiviteterna kommer att genomföras av ett konsortium av internationella civilsamhällesorganisationer: SvK, ACF, NRC och LWF.
Sidas avtalspartner kommer att vara Trossamfundet Svenska Kyrkan, en internationell icke-statlig organisation med registreringsnummer 252002-6135, 751 70 Uppsala, Sverige, med kontor i Uganda. Avtalsutkastet som kommer undertecknas av SvK och Sida har tagits fram med tillämpning av Sidas avtalsmall för bidrag från Sida till enskilda organisationer angående projekt/programstöd (version 1.2 Oktober 2018), med stöd från Sidas juridiska enhet.
SvK kommer att vara Sidas samarbetspartner och ansvarar för ledning och samordning av partners, framtagande och inlämning av arbetsplaner, budgetar, årsredovisning, finansiella rapporter och andra rapporter till Sida, säkerställande av uppföljning av avtalsvillkor, Sidas regler och hantering av partners.
SvK:s programkontor kommer att ansvara för genomförandet av programmet och kommer att vidareförmedla medel för implementering av MIRP till de tre genomförandepartnerna NRC, LWF och ACF. De tre konsortiepartnerna har genomfört olika program i Uganda i över 20 år och har väl etablerade kontor, personal, system och rutiner för att leverera förväntade resultat. SvK kommer att teckna avtal med de tre konsortiepartnerna med egna regler och förfaranden, som utgår från det avtal som Sida och SvK kommer att underteckna.
NRC, ACF och LWF kommer att genomföra aktiviteter baserade på överenskomna budget- och arbetsplaner. Fokusområden och budget för de tre genomförandepartnerna (2019-2023) är som följer:
NRC - Utbildning, läskunnighet och sysselsättning - 42 015 176 SEK ACF - Försörjningsmöjligheter och livsmedelssäkerhet - 42 015 176 SEK LWF - Miljö och förnybar energi samt vatten och sanitet, Sexuell reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter - 42 015 176 SEK För SvK att förvalta och samordna konsortiet - 26 068 740 SEK
Ett oöronmärkt stöd på 5% (7 605 715 SEK) av den totala budgeten kommer att tillhandahållas som beredskap för oförutsedda omständigheter i sammanhanget, till exempel snabb ökning av flyktingar, uppkomst av sjukdomsutbrott etc. Medel under denna budget kommer endast att användas efter godkännande av Sida.
MIRP kommer att utgå från ett flexibelt tillvägagångssätt genom pilotstudier, bedömningar, lärande och anpassning för att tillhandahålla effektiva lösningar kopplat till nexus mellan humanitärt stöd och utvecklingssamarbete. En uppstartsfas på sex månader har lagts in i början av programmet för att möjliggöra genomförande av olika studier, framtagande av baslinjer samt djupgående samråd och revision av programbudgeten och resultatramverket. Genomförandet kommer också att främja lärande hos genomförandepartnerna och partners aktiva i flyktingresponsen och insatsen syftar till att informera Ugandas flyktingramverk Compehensive Refugee Response Framework – CRRF, med focus på hållbara lösningar för flyktingar.

The Mutual and Inter-Related Resilience Programme (MIRP) 2019-2023) as proposed by a consortium of partners i.e Church of Sweden (CoS), Action Against Hunger (ACF), Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) aims at piloting a programme aimed at creating durable solutions for refugees and host communities in Western Uganda around Kyangwali Refugee Settlement and surrounding areas, focusing on the nexus between humanitarian response and development.
Uganda’s progressive refugee policy promotes initiatives that push the refugee agenda beyond humanitarian relief to long term development and empowerment of refugees and host communities to find durable solutions. The untenable conditions in countries of origins for refugees such as the conflict in South Sudan and Democratic Republic of Congo make the current refugees in Uganda unlikely to return to their countries at least in the short term, necessitating programming of interventions that aim at integration of refugees within Uganda.
A number of actions have been implemented towards the refugee integration agenda such as the Self-reliance strategy of 1998, Development Assistance to Refugee-Hosting Areas programme (2004) and the current Settlement Transformative Agenda (STA) that aims at assisting refugees and host communities by promoting self-reliance, investment and social economic development in refugee-hosting areas. Based on these previous interventions, the MIRP contribution is aimed at addressing existing persistent gaps that need to be addressed to achieve self-reliance, resilience and development in Kyangwali Refugee Settlement and surrounding areas.
The overall goal of MIRP is to ensure that Right-holders (target communities including refugees and host communities) have achieved resilient communities and experience increased economic self-reliance and psychosocial well-being by end of the programme in 2023.The programme aims to achieve this objective through solution oriented actions that address both immediate essential needs and while at the same time strengthening local capacity and development of long term sustainable solutions for the protracted refugee crisis in Kyangwali and surrounding areas.
The intended outcomes of the MIRP intervention are: 1. Improved quality of literacy, numeracy and skills development in Kyangwali resettlement and surrounding districts 2. Improved Livelihoods and food security for both host and refugees 3. Environmental protection and sustainable energy for both host and refugees and 4. Increased access to WASH and Protection (including GBV prevention and promotion of gender justice) and SRH services
The MIRP programme foresees a “resilient community” as “a community where members are actively engaged in socioeconomic development and basic needs of vulnerable members are addressed”. The programme targets to increase the capacity of Hoima and Kikuube district local governments to plan and integrate refugee issues through support to key infrastructure and services in key sectors like education, health, water, agriculture extension, livelihoods and skills development.
In education, literacy, numeracy and skills development, the programme aims at increased employability, income generation opportunities among the youth through skill training programmes, increased knowledge and skills (market oriented vocations, life skills, entrepreneurship, language, literacy and numeracy). It will support establishment of infrastructure such as classrooms and pit latrines and support water and sanitation in schools aimed at factors of high school dropout rates.
The programme will support interventions that support livelihood and food security for both refugee and host communities through maximizing the use of land plots allocated to refugees through climate smart actions, use of improved inputs, agricultural extension, commercial farming in host communities and micro-irrigation.
The programme is further expected to address environmental degradation associated with the refugee settlement and dependency on wood for energy. To avoid environmental harm, an environmental risk assessment and plan for Kyangwali and its environs will be conducted to identify necessary action to address issues related to degradation of natural resources and environment. Other actions relate to sustainable renewable energy solutions, proper waste disposal and increased environmental awareness.
The programme will support Water and Sanitation, Sexual Reproductive Health and Protection services (including Gender Based Violence Prevention and Gender Justice): These activities are deemed critical to address current gaps in addressing SGBV such as limited opportunities for female refugees, vulnerability to risks of sexual exploitation, long distances to collect water and other resources. It will address existing gaps in sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) services
The intervention’s total budget is 159,720,000 SEK all funded by Sida implemented by a consortium of international Non-Governmental organisations i.e CoS, ACF, NRC and LWF.
The Agreement Partner will be Church of Sweden (Trossamfundet Svenska kyrkan), an International NGO registered in as registration number 252002-6135, SE-751 70 Uppsala, Sweden) with an office in Uganda. A draft agreement to be signed by CoS and Sida has been prepared using a template and General Conditions applicable to Grants from Sida to NGO’s, regarding project/programme support and core support (ver 1.2_20181011) as advised by the Sida Legal Unit and is hereby attached.CoS will be Sida’s Agreement partner and is responsible for management and coordination of partners, preparation and submission of work plans, budgets, Annual Narrative, Financial and other reports to Sida, ensuring follow up of agreement conditions, sida rules and procedures with partners.
CoS will operate a programme office that will be responsible for the implementation of the programme and will sub-grant implementation of the MIRP to the three implementation partners NRC, LWF and ACF. The three consortium partners have implemented various programmes in Uganda for over 20 years and have well established offices, personnel, systems and procedures to deliver the programme. CoS will sign agreement with the 3 consortium partners using its own rules and procedures but these must be in line with the agreement signed between Sida and CoS in respect to this agreement.
NRC, ACF and LWF will implement actions in particular but related sectors based on agreed budget and work plans. The indicative sectors for the three implementing partners (2019-2023) and indicative budgets are as follows:
NRC - Literacy, Numeracy and skills for business and employment - 42,015,176 SEK ACF - Livelihoods and food security - 42,015,176 SEK LWF - Environment and Renewable Energy and Water and sanitation, Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights - 42,015,176 SEK For church of Sweden for managing and coordinating the consortium -26,068,740SEK
A contingency of 5% (7,605,715 SEK) has been provided in the budget as contingency for unforeseen circumstances in the context such as rapid refugee influx, emergence of disease out breaks etc. The funds under this budget will only be utilised after request to and approval by Sida.
The MIRP will use a flexible approach of piloting, assessment, learning and adjusting to provide fitting solutions to the humanitarian and development nexus. As such an Inception phase of six months has been provided at the start of the programme to allow for conducting of various studies, conducting in depth consultations, and revision of the programme budget and the Results Framework. The implementation will also promote cross-learning among the implementation partners and will provide input to the Comprehensive Refugee Framework that seeks durable solution for refugee emergencies.

The overall goal of the intervention is to ensure that Right-holders have achieved resilient communities and experienced increased economic self-reliance and psychosocial well-being. This will be achieved through solutions-oriented action that addresses both immediate essential needs while at the same time strengthening local capacity and enabling local ownership for long-term sustainable solutions to the protracted displacement crisis. The intended outcomes of the intervention are: 1. Improved quality of literacy, numeracy and skills development in Kyangwali resettlement and surrounding districts2. Improved Livelihoods and food security for both host and refugees3. Environmental protection and sustainable energy for both host and refugees and4. Increased access to WASH and Protection (including GBV prevention and promotion of gender justice) and SRH services The operational definition for a “resilient community” has been defined by the consortia as “a community where members are actively engaged in socio-economic development and basic needs of vulnerable members are addressed”.

description.narrative:
The project has completed the first year of implementation and it is too early to assess its impact. The impact of the project will be assessed in the subsequent periods. However, a number of processes and outputs necessary to achieve project objectives and future impact were achieved, notably:
1. Completion of the baseline studies: A set of data was collected and used to refine the Results Framework as a basis for monitoring and evaluation of the project. The baseline highlighted and confirmed a number of challenges facing refugees and host communities in Kyangwali refugee camp and surrounding areas including lack of and use of basic services like Sexual Reproductive Health Rights and services (SRHR), hygiene, sanitation, skills training, agro-ecological farming practices. It further indicated that a high level of Gender Based Violence (physical, sexual and emotional). Following the baseline, a number of adjustments were made in the programme e.g. strong inclusion of marginalised people with disabilities, better targeting of beneficiaries, inclusion of new or adjustment of some of the outcomes in the Results Framework.
2. Mini-workshops were conducted with experts and stakeholders including UNHCR, Office of the Prime Minister, Kikuube District Local Governments, other NGOs and consortium staff covering topics like community based psychological approach, gender and conflict sensitivity. In terms of Project Result Areas, the following achievements were made during the period:
Result Area 1: Enhanced sustainable livelihoods and nutrition sensitive agricultural resilience of household refugees and host communities in around Kyangwali.
This result area aims at addressing the limited access to land for agriculture, limited employment and access to capital. Completed activities during the period included profiling of target beneficiary farmers, training of trainers (staff), selection of agro-input suppliers for supply of agricultural inputs for vulnerable households, selection of a consultant to support income generating activities and identification of local partner to support outcome area on increased household resilience through management of income and finance and training of Village Savings and Loan Associations and linking them to micro-finance institutions.
Result Area 2: Improving literacy, numeracy and developing skills for increased resilience and contribution to inclusive economic development. This result area aims at addressing low numeracy and literacy within refugees and host communities. Findings from the baseline have indicated that only 33% of refugees and 67% of host communities' children of school going age are actually attending school. During the period, procurement of Water and sanitation, hygiene kits, personnel protection equipment to support key service providers was completed. Identification of 8 vocational schools within Hoima and Kikuube and their capacity needs assessment was carried out. Key areas identified include need for development of strategic plans, inadequate training, resource mobilisation, financial management skills, board roles, development of curriculum and main streaming life skills. Key required skills were identified in building and concrete practice, carpentry, joinery, hair dressing, knitting and weaving, catering and hotel management, motorcycle repairs, plumbing, electoral installation, tailoring and crafts technology. In addition, recruitment of 44 teachers to support teaching and Accelerated learning, procurement of school supplies, recreation materials and re-usable sanitary pads was completed. In addition, procurement processes for construction of classroom blocks and improved pit latrines in 3 schools in host and refugee areas was completed and architectural plans were submitted to the district for approval.
Result Area 3: Increased access to WASH and Protection (SGBV).
Assessments during inception phase indicated that 14% of refugees and 45% of host community households were using unsafe water, there was limited access to sanitation and hygiene as 10% of the population use open defecation. SGBV is highly prevalent both in refugees and host communities and only 13% of the women and girls reported to have used family planning in the last 12 months.
During the period, 23 Village Health Teams from 12 villages were supported and they reached out to 8,525 people with targeted sanitation messages. They were further supported with sanitizers, hand gloves and face masks. A baseline census conducted in 12 villages as part of covering 2230 households and survey of 72 water sources indicated that 36% of Households had access to 20 litres of water per day, latrine coverage was at 79% while functional latrines stood at 29%.
To address GBV, 15 dialogues on causes and effects of SGBV were held jointly with Kikuube local governments, police and the district health inspector, and with the community structures. 22 GBV incidences were identified, responded to and psychosocial support provided.
Result Area 4: Improving sustainable use and protection of natural resources and sustainable energy.
Under this result area, 42 community-based facilitators were identified and trained in environmental protection on topics on agroforestry, soil and water conservation, tree planting and watershed management. 60 individuals were trained in improved cook stoves, 4 dark spots for SGBV identified for auto solar installation while 2 Nursery operators were identified to supply tree seedlings.
Effect of the Covid-19 pandemic on implementation.
Due to the Covid-19 outbreak in Uganda and the subsequent implementation of a lock down from March 2020, the implementation of a number of activities were affected, especially those dependent on group meetings such as farmer training, supplies by agro-input dealers. A number of studies such as on gender, peace and conflict and environmental analysis were delayed and will be completed during 2021.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
